Additionally, loans must not be netted with Deposits. [#P:3a93882f-1af7-4a78-bb19-7050e7fb32af] The Leverage Ratio itself is calculated by dividing the Capital Measure, which represents the Tier 1 Capital of the Authorised Person, by the Exposure Measure, which is the value of Exposures calculated as described. [#P:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] This approach ensures that the Leverage Ratio reflects a true and fair view of the Authorised Person's financial position, without artificially reducing exposure values through netting or collateral adjustments.

question: How must an Authorised Person calculate its Leverage Ratio, and what components are required to determine the Exposure Measure under Rule 3.21.2(b)?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to calculate its Leverage Ratio using the formula: Leverage Ratio = Capital Measure / Exposure Measure [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b]. The Capital Measure is defined as the Tier 1 Capital of the Authorised Person, calculated according to Rule 3.9.1 [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b]. The Exposure Measure, as specified under Rule 3.21.2(b), must include the sum of on-balance sheet items and off-balance sheet items [#TGT:7cb04504-3a85-4cd6-9010-652aec3cc07c]. Therefore, the Exposure Measure is a critical component in determining the Leverage Ratio, and it must be calculated by aggregating these specified items [#TGT:7cb04504-3a85-4cd6-9010-652aec3cc07c].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person must calculate its Leverage Ratio by dividing its Capital Measure by its Exposure Measure. The Capital Measure is defined as the Tier 1 Capital of the Authorised Person, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.9.1 [#P:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b]. The Exposure Measure, as required under Rule 3.21.2(b), is determined by summing the on-balance sheet items and off-balance sheet items [#P:7cb04504-3a85-4cd6-9010-652aec3cc07c]. For the Exposure Measure, the value of Exposures must be calculated according to the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS), with specific adjustments: on-balance sheet, non-Derivative Exposures should be net of specific allowances and valuation adjustments; physical or financial Collateral, guarantees, or other credit risk mitigation techniques must not reduce exposure values; and loans must not be netted with Deposits [#P:3a93882f-1af7-4a78-bb19-7050e7fb32af]. This methodology ensures that the Leverage Ratio accurately reflects the financial position of the Authorised Person, adhering to regulatory standards.

question: How does an Authorised Person figure out its Leverage Ratio, and what should be included in the Exposure Measure?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person calculates its Leverage Ratio by dividing the Capital Measure by the Exposure Measure [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b]. The Capital Measure is the Tier 1 Capital, determined by Rule 3.9.1 [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b]. For the Exposure Measure, Rule 3.21.2(b) states it must include both on-balance sheet and off-balance sheet items [#TGT:7cb04504-3a85-4cd6-9010-652aec3cc07c]. These components are essential for accurately calculating the Leverage Ratio [#TGT:7cb04504-3a85-4cd6-9010-652aec3cc07c].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person calculates its Leverage Ratio by dividing its Capital Measure by its Exposure Measure. The Capital Measure is defined as the Tier 1 Capital of the Authorised Person, calculated according to Rule 3.9.1 [#P:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b]. The Exposure Measure includes the value of Exposures of the Authorised Person, which must be calculated in accordance with Rules 3.21.5 and 3.21.6 [#P:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b]. Additionally, the Authorised Person must ensure that it holds sufficient Tier 1 Capital to maintain a minimum Leverage Ratio of 3% or as otherwise set by the Regulator [#P:e9e2bf18-6110-4e9f-8060-c59b85e5cd8e]. This calculation is crucial for maintaining regulatory compliance and ensuring the financial stability of the Authorised Person. It is important to note that the Exposure Measure should comprehensively reflect the value of all Exposures, and the Authorised Person must adhere to any specific requirements or exemptions as outlined in the relevant sections of the regulatory framework.

question: What are the obligations of an Authorised Person regarding CET1 Capital at the time of obtaining authorisation and subsequently, considering the definitions and requirements in Rule 3.3.3 and Section 3.10?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to maintain a minimum amount of Common Equity Tier 1 Capital (CET1 Capital) that meets or exceeds its Base Capital Requirement at the time of obtaining authorisation and continuously thereafter [#SRC:ef0be50a-35f4-4cfc-92c5-c7fd6d52a32b]. This obligation applies to all Authorised Persons, irrespective of their category, and is defined in Section 3.10 [#TGT:f7a7169f-e5db-4678-9284-868409b88d8a]. The requirement ensures that the Authorised Person's CET1 Capital is not less than the relevant Base Capital Requirement at any point in time [#TGT:f7a7169f-e5db-4678-9284-868409b88d8a].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person is required to maintain a minimum amount of Common Equity Tier 1 Capital (CET1 Capital) at the time of obtaining authorisation and continuously thereafter, in accordance with Rule 3.3.3 and Section 3.10. This obligation ensures that the Authorised Person meets its Base Capital Requirement at all times. The CET1 Capital must be calculated by deducting specific items such as current financial year losses, goodwill, intangible assets, and certain holdings in CET1 Capital instruments, among others, as detailed in Section 3.10.7 [#P:f7a7169f-e5db-4678-9284-868409b88d8a][#P:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]. Additionally, the Authorised Person must maintain a required buffer amount as CET1 Capital, calculated according to Rule 3.18.4, to ensure ongoing compliance with capital adequacy requirements [#P:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf]. These obligations are critical for maintaining financial stability and regulatory compliance, and failure to adhere to these requirements could result in regulatory action.

question: What must an Authorised Person do about CET1 Capital when they get authorised and after that?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must ensure that their Common Equity Tier 1 Capital (CET1 Capital) is at least equal to their Base Capital Requirement both when they get authorised and at all times after that [#SRC:ef0be50a-35f4-4cfc-92c5-c7fd6d52a32b]. This requirement applies to all Authorised Persons, no matter their category, and is detailed in Section 3.10 [#TGT:f7a7169f-e5db-4678-9284-868409b88d8a].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person must carefully manage its CET1 Capital both at the time of authorisation and continuously thereafter. Initially, the Authorised Person must ensure that its CET1 Capital calculations exclude certain items, such as increases in equity under IFRS related to future margin income and unrealised gains or losses on liabilities valued at fair value due to changes in its own credit quality [#P:6e1d64e5-60c2-4627-af1c-f05e612f92bc]. Additionally, they must deduct specific items from CET1 Capital, including current financial year losses, goodwill, and certain holdings of CET1 Capital instruments [#P:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]. If the Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must prepare and submit a capital conservation plan to the Regulator within five business days, detailing measures to increase CET1 Capital and a plan to restore the Combined Buffer [#P:7a946965-716a-431a-b643-57f91e0ff92e]. These steps ensure that the Authorised Person maintains adequate capital levels and complies with regulatory requirements.

question: How must an Authorised Person incorporate the Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM) into the overall calculation of its Risk Capital Requirement, considering the components outlined in the relevant Rules and the supplementary guidance provided in App4?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to calculate its Risk Capital Requirement by summing several components, one of which is the Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM) [#TGT:d644e5de-c570-425e-9197-0fe073f269ac]. The CRCOM is specifically governed by the Rules in Part 3, which are further supplemented by App4, detailing the manner of its calculation [#SRC:c03600d2-2dac-495b-bba4-fe457d5e7166]. In addition to the CRCOM, the Risk Capital Requirement includes the Market Risk Capital Requirement, Operational Risk Capital Requirement, Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement (where applicable), and the CVA Risk Capital Requirement [#TGT:d644e5de-c570-425e-9197-0fe073f269ac]. The comprehensive calculation of these components ensures the Authorised Person meets its overall Capital Requirement obligations as outlined in the Rules [#SRC:c03600d2-2dac-495b-bba4-fe457d5e7166].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person must incorporate the Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM) into its overall Risk Capital Requirement by following a structured approach as outlined in the relevant Rules. The CRCOM is a critical component of the overall Capital Requirement calculation, which also includes Market Risk, Operational Risk, Displaced Commercial Risk (where applicable), and CVA Risk Capital Requirements [#P:d644e5de-c570-425e-9197-0fe073f269ac]. Specifically, the Authorised Person must calculate the CRCOM in accordance with the applicable Rules in Chapter 4, which are further supplemented by guidance in Appendix 4 (App4) [#P:c03600d2-2dac-495b-bba4-fe457d5e7166; #P:8b8d4332-205d-4188-b48d-748ecc15479a]. This structured calculation ensures that the Authorised Person adequately accounts for credit risk exposure as part of its comprehensive risk management strategy. The CRCOM, along with other risk capital requirements, forms the basis for determining the total capital that the Authorised Person must hold to meet regulatory standards and safeguard against potential financial risks.

question: What does an Authorised Person need to do to include the Credit Risk Capital Requirement in its total Risk Capital Requirement, and what other parts are involved?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person needs to calculate its Risk Capital Requirement by adding together several parts, including the Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM) [#TGT:d644e5de-c570-425e-9197-0fe073f269ac]. Besides the CRCOM, the total also includes the Market Risk Capital Requirement, Operational Risk Capital Requirement, Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement if it applies, and the CVA Risk Capital Requirement [#TGT:d644e5de-c570-425e-9197-0fe073f269ac]. This ensures the Authorised Person meets its overall Capital Requirement as required by the Rules [#SRC:c03600d2-2dac-495b-bba4-fe457d5e7166].

These components include the Credit Risk Capital Requirement itself, the Market Risk Capital Requirement, the Operational Risk Capital Requirement, the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement (where applicable), and the CVA Risk Capital Requirement. [#P:d644e5de-c570-425e-9197-0fe073f269ac] The Credit Risk Capital Requirement is a fundamental part of the Risk Capital Requirement, which forms the Capital Requirement for Authorised Persons in Categories 1, 2, or 5. These entities must ensure they hold sufficient total Capital Resources of the required quality to meet specified capital ratios, any Individual Capital Requirement, the Combined Buffer, and any other applicable buffer. [#P:6baecaf1-9191-4b1b-a80e-08438f4d8ef8] It is important to note that if an Authorised Person's Foreign Currency business does not exceed 100% of its Capital Resources and its overall net open position does not exceed 2% of its Capital Resources, it need not calculate a Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement. [#P:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97] This comprehensive approach ensures that all relevant risk factors are accounted for in the total Risk Capital Requirement.

question: How must an Authorised Person calculate its Credit Risk Capital Requirement, considering the provisions in both Part 3 and Chapter 4 of the Rules?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to calculate its Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM) by adhering to the applicable Rules outlined in both Part 3 and Chapter 4. The overall Capital Requirement, of which CRCOM is a component, is governed by the Rules in Part 3, specifically Rules 3.5.1 and 3.5.2, and is further supplemented by Appendix 4 [#SRC:c03600d2-2dac-495b-bba4-fe457d5e7166]. Additionally, Chapter 4 provides specific applicable Rules that must be followed for the calculation of CRCOM [#TGT:8b8d4332-205d-4188-b48d-748ecc15479a]. Therefore, compliance with both sections is essential for the accurate calculation of the Credit Risk Capital Requirement.

Specifically, Part 3 provides the framework for calculating Capital Requirements, which applies to all firms but includes differentiated calculations for various Categories of Authorised Persons as prescribed in Sections 3.4 and 3.6 [#P:daf2ec63-a8a3-4cd4-b0e3-450154245ed4]. Chapter 4 further details the calculation of the Credit Risk Capital Requirement, ensuring that Authorised Persons adhere to the specific methodologies and provisions outlined therein [#P:8b8d4332-205d-4188-b48d-748ecc15479a]. It is essential for Authorised Persons to follow these guidelines precisely to ensure compliance with the regulatory standards set forth by the ADGM/FSRA.

question: When an Authorised Person calculates its Credit Risk Capital Requirement, what parts of the Rules should they follow?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must follow the Rules in both Part 3 and Chapter 4 when calculating its Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM). Part 3, including Rules 3.5.1 and 3.5.2, along with Appendix 4, outlines the overall Capital Requirement, of which CRCOM is a part [#SRC:c03600d2-2dac-495b-bba4-fe457d5e7166]. Chapter 4 specifies the applicable Rules that must be adhered to for CRCOM calculation [#TGT:8b8d4332-205d-4188-b48d-748ecc15479a]. Thus, both sections are necessary for proper compliance.

question: How must an Authorised Person calculate its Credit Risk Capital Requirement, considering the provisions in Part 3 and Chapter 4?

question: How must an Authorised Person determine the eligible minority interests of a Subsidiary for inclusion in consolidated CET1 Capital, considering the calculation of Total Risk Exposure Amount?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must determine the eligible minority interests of a Subsidiary for inclusion in its consolidated CET1 Capital by subtracting a specific calculated amount from the minority interests of that Subsidiary. This calculation involves subtracting the lesser of two values from the CET1 Capital of the Subsidiary: (i) the amount required to meet the Subsidiary's CET1 Capital requirement of 6.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount on a solo basis, or (ii) the amount required on a consolidated basis to meet the Financial Group's CET1 Capital requirement of 6.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount [#SRC:dc108b2b-6b01-433d-9e1b-09159c329ab0]. The Total Risk Exposure Amount itself is calculated by summing the Credit RWA, Market Risk Capital Requirement, Operational Risk Capital Requirement, CVA Risk Capital Requirement, and, where applicable, the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e].
rag_answer: To determine the eligible minority interests of a Subsidiary for inclusion in consolidated CET1 Capital, an Authorised Person must follow a specific calculation process. First, the Authorised Person must identify the minority interests of the Subsidiary. Then, they must subtract from these minority interests the result of multiplying a specific amount by a percentage. The amount to be subtracted is the CET1 Capital of the Subsidiary minus the lesser of two values: (i) the amount of CET1 Capital required to meet the Subsidiary's CET1 Capital requirement of 6.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount, plus its Combined Buffer Requirement, or (ii) the amount of consolidated CET1 Capital required on a consolidated basis to meet the Financial Group's CET1 Capital requirement of 6.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount, plus its Combined Buffer Requirement [#P:dc108b2b-6b01-433d-9e1b-09159c329ab0]. The percentage used in the multiplication is the minority interests of the Subsidiary expressed as a percentage of all CET1 Capital instruments of that Undertaking, plus the related retained earnings and Share premium accounts [#P:dc108b2b-6b01-433d-9e1b-09159c329ab0]. This process ensures that only the eligible portion of minority interests is included in the consolidated CET1 Capital.

question: How does an Authorised Person figure out the minority interests of a Subsidiary that can be included in CET1 Capital, and what is the Total Risk Exposure Amount?

question: How must an Authorised Person determine the amount of qualifying T1 Capital of a Subsidiary included in its consolidated T1 Capital, considering the calculation of Total Risk Exposure Amount?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must determine the amount of qualifying T1 Capital of a Subsidiary included in its consolidated T1 Capital by subtracting a specific calculated amount from the qualifying T1 Capital of that Subsidiary. This calculation involves determining the lesser of two amounts: the T1 Capital required to meet the Subsidiary's solo T1 Capital requirement of 8.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount, or the consolidated T1 Capital required to meet the Financial Group's T1 Capital requirement of 8.0% of the Total Risk Exposure Amount [#SRC:848dd3a2-e7e9-4e76-81cd-55b3105d6d14]. The Total Risk Exposure Amount itself is calculated as the sum of several components, including Credit RWA, Market Risk, Operational Risk, CVA Risk, and Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirements, as per Rule 3.5.8 [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e].
rag_answer: To determine the amount of qualifying T1 Capital of a Subsidiary included in its consolidated T1 Capital, an Authorised Person must follow a specific calculation process. The specific amount is the lesser of two values: (i) the T1 Capital of the Subsidiary required to meet the sum of its T1 Capital requirement (on a solo basis) of 8.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount and its Combined Buffer Requirement, or (ii) the amount of consolidated T1 Capital that relates to the Subsidiary required on a consolidated basis to meet the sum of its Financial Group's T1 Capital requirement of 8.0% of the Total Risk Exposure Amount and its Combined Buffer Requirement [#P:848dd3a2-e7e9-4e76-81cd-55b3105d6d14]. The percentage used in the multiplication is the qualifying T1 Capital of the Subsidiary expressed as a percentage of all T1 Capital instruments of that Subsidiary plus the related retained earnings and Share premium accounts [#P:848dd3a2-e7e9-4e76-81cd-55b3105d6d14]. This process ensures that the consolidated T1 Capital accurately reflects the financial position of the Authorised Person's Financial Group.

question: How must an Authorised Person determine the qualifying Capital Resources of a Subsidiary included in the consolidated Capital Resources of its Financial Group, considering the calculation of the Total Risk Exposure Amount?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must determine the qualifying Capital Resources of a Subsidiary included in the consolidated Capital Resources of its Financial Group by subtracting a specific amount from the Subsidiary's qualifying Capital Resources. This specific amount is calculated by multiplying the lesser of two values by a percentage. The first value is the amount of Capital Resources required to meet the Subsidiary's total Capital Requirement, which is 10.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated according to Rule 3.5.7, and its Combined Buffer Requirement [#SRC:9828ecf6-13e6-4602-802b-b198835d9d99]. The Total Risk Exposure Amount itself is the sum of several components, including the Credit RWA, Market Risk Capital Requirement, Operational Risk Capital Requirement, CVA Risk Capital Requirement, and Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement, as calculated under various rules [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e].
rag_answer: To determine the qualifying Capital Resources of a Subsidiary included in the consolidated Capital Resources of its Financial Group, an Authorised Person must follow a specific calculation method. The process involves subtracting from the qualifying Capital Resources of the Subsidiary the result of multiplying a specified amount by a percentage. The amount to be subtracted is the lesser of two values: (i) the amount of Capital Resources required for the Subsidiary to meet its total Capital Requirement on a solo basis, which is 10.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount plus its Combined Buffer Requirement, or (ii) the amount of Capital Resources required on a consolidated basis for the Financial Group to meet its total Capital Requirement, also 10.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount plus its Combined Buffer Requirement [#P:9828ecf6-13e6-4602-802b-b198835d9d99]. The percentage used in the calculation is the qualifying Capital Resources of the Subsidiary expressed as a percentage of all Capital Resources instruments of the Subsidiary included in its CET1, AT1, and T2 Capital items, along with related retained earnings and Share premium accounts [#P:9828ecf6-13e6-4602-802b-b198835d9d99]. This method ensures that only the appropriate portion of a Subsidiary's Capital Resources is included in the consolidated Capital Resources of the Financial Group.

question: When figuring out how much of a Subsidiary's Capital Resources count for the whole Financial Group, what must an Authorised Person do with the Total Risk Exposure Amount?
gold_answer: To figure out how much of a Subsidiary's Capital Resources count for the whole Financial Group, an Authorised Person must subtract a calculated amount from the Subsidiary's qualifying Capital Resources. This involves multiplying the lesser of two values by a percentage. One of these values is based on the Subsidiary's total Capital Requirement, which is 10.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated using Rule 3.5.7, along with its Combined Buffer Requirement [#SRC:9828ecf6-13e6-4602-802b-b198835d9d99]. The Total Risk Exposure Amount includes several risk components, such as Credit RWA and Market Risk, calculated under specific rules [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e].
rag_answer: To determine how much of a Subsidiary's Capital Resources count for the whole Financial Group, an Authorised Person must carefully consider the Total Risk Exposure Amount. The process involves several key steps. This is done by subtracting a specific amount from the Subsidiary's qualifying Capital Resources. The amount to be subtracted is determined by multiplying the lesser of two values by a percentage. The first value is the amount of Capital Resources required to meet the Subsidiary's total Capital Requirement, which is 10.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount, plus its Combined Buffer Requirement, calculated on a solo basis. The second value is the amount of Capital Resources required on a consolidated basis to meet the Financial Group's total Capital Requirement, also 10.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount, plus its Combined Buffer Requirement [#P:9828ecf6-13e6-4602-802b-b198835d9d99]. Additionally, the Authorised Person must ensure that the Capital Resources or Adjusted Capital Resources of subsidiaries are not included if they exceed the entity requirement or are not freely transferable within the Financial Group [#P:e0096bb2-da49-4bde-84a1-cdbe953d165f].

question: How must an Authorised Person calculate its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital, considering the Total Risk Exposure Amount and the applicable buffer rates?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to calculate its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by first determining its Total Risk Exposure Amount. This amount must be calculated as the sum of several components: the Credit RWA, the Risk Exposure Amounts for Market Risk, Operational Risk, CVA Risk, and, if applicable, Displaced Commercial Risk, as specified in the relevant rules [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]. Once the Total Risk Exposure Amount is established, it must be multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates applicable to the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, as outlined in Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8 [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person must calculate its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by determining the Total Risk Exposure Amount and applying the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates applicable to its private sector credit exposures across different jurisdictions. The process involves several key steps: (a) For each jurisdiction where the Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures, divide the Total Risk Exposure Amount related to those exposures by the Total Risk Exposure Amount across all jurisdictions, and multiply this by the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate for that jurisdiction [#P:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124]. (b) Sum the contributions from all jurisdictions to obtain the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates [#P:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124]. (c) Multiply the Total Risk Exposure Amount by this weighted average to determine the Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital [#P:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]. It is crucial for the Authorised Person to accurately identify the geographical location of its credit exposures, defined as the jurisdiction where the underlying credit risk originates, to ensure the correct application of buffer rates [#P:ffc672ed-a781-4a71-bb0d-7fc38a2e0c7c]. This method ensures that the buffer reflects the risk profile of the Authorised Person's credit exposures across different regions.

question: How does an Authorised Person figure out its Countercyclical Capital Buffer using the Total Risk Exposure Amount and buffer rates?
gold_answer: To determine its Countercyclical Capital Buffer, an Authorised Person must first calculate the Total Risk Exposure Amount. This involves adding together the Credit RWA and the Risk Exposure Amounts for Market Risk, Operational Risk, CVA Risk, and possibly Displaced Commercial Risk, following the specified rules [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]. After calculating this total, the Authorised Person multiplies it by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates for the areas where its private sector credit exposures are located, as per the relevant rules [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c].

The weighted average is determined by identifying the geographical location of the private sector credit exposures, which is the jurisdiction where the underlying credit risk originates [#P:ffc672ed-a781-4a71-bb0d-7fc38a2e0c7c]. For each jurisdiction, the Total Risk Exposure Amount related to the private sector credit exposures is divided by the Total Risk Exposure Amount across all jurisdictions, and this ratio is multiplied by the jurisdiction's Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate [#P:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124]. These contributions are then summed across all jurisdictions to obtain the weighted average buffer rate [#P:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124]. This calculated buffer ensures that the Authorised Person maintains sufficient capital to absorb potential losses during periods of economic stress.

question: How must an Authorised Person calculate the Total Risk Exposure Amount, and what specific multiplication factor is applied to certain capital requirements?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to calculate the Total Risk Exposure Amount by summing several specific Risk Exposure Amounts. These include the Credit RWA, Market Risk Capital Requirement, Operational Risk Capital Requirement, CVA Risk Capital Requirement, and, where applicable, the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement [#SRC:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]. To determine the Risk Exposure Amounts associated with the Market Risk, Operational Risk, CVA Risk, and Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirements, the Authorised Person must multiply the individual capital requirements by a factor of 12.5 [#TGT:c6eab1e6-6274-4d4d-b4b7-22ad0f9fe1c1].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person must calculate the Total Risk Exposure Amount by summing several specific risk exposure amounts, and a multiplication factor is applied to certain capital requirements. To determine the Risk Exposure Amounts for the Market, Operational, CVA, and Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirements, an Authorised Person must multiply these individual capital requirements by a factor of 12.5 [#P:c6eab1e6-6274-4d4d-b4b7-22ad0f9fe1c1]. This calculation ensures that the Total Risk Exposure Amount accurately reflects the various risks faced by the Authorised Person, allowing for appropriate capital allocation and regulatory compliance.

question: What steps must an Authorised Person take to calculate the Total Risk Exposure Amount, and how are certain parts of it adjusted?
gold_answer: To calculate the Total Risk Exposure Amount, an Authorised Person must add together several Risk Exposure Amounts, including those for Credit, Market, Operational, CVA, and Displaced Commercial Risks [#SRC:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]. For the Market, Operational, CVA, and Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirements, the Authorised Person needs to multiply each by 12.5 to determine the associated Risk Exposure Amounts [#TGT:c6eab1e6-6274-4d4d-b4b7-22ad0f9fe1c1].
rag_answer: To calculate the Total Risk Exposure Amount, an Authorised Person must follow a specific procedure that involves several key steps and adjustments. First, the Total Risk Exposure Amount is determined as the sum of various risk exposure amounts: the Credit RWA, the Market Risk Capital Requirement, the Operational Risk Capital Requirement, the CVA Risk Capital Requirement, and, where applicable, the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement [#P:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]. The individual capital requirements for the Market Risk, Operational Risk, CVA Risk, and Displaced Commercial Risk must then be multiplied by a factor of 12.5 to determine their respective Risk Exposure Amounts [#P:c6eab1e6-6274-4d4d-b4b7-22ad0f9fe1c1]. This calculated Total Risk Exposure Amount is crucial for ensuring compliance with capital ratio requirements, such as maintaining a minimum CET1 Capital ratio of 6.0%, a T1 Capital ratio of 8.0%, and a Capital Resources ratio of 10.0% [#P:f70e13d5-e8a2-464c-871c-7306c244548d]. These steps ensure that the Authorised Person accurately assesses its risk exposure and maintains the necessary capital buffers.

question: How must a Money Remitter determine its Capital Requirement, considering both the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum and the Variable Capital Requirement?
gold_answer: A Money Remitter must calculate its Capital Requirement by determining the highest value among several specified components. The calculation involves the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum as outlined in Section 3.7 and the Variable Capital Requirement. The Variable Capital Requirement is calculated as the sum of percentages applied to different tiers of monthly payment volume: 1.25% of the first $10 million, 0.5% of the next $90 million, 0.25% of the next $150 million, and 0.125% of any remaining volume [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304][#TGT:b1b3ae34-d42b-4c08-83fb-9ddac72f228c].
rag_answer: A Money Remitter must determine its Capital Requirement by considering both the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum and the Variable Capital Requirement, selecting the highest value among these. The Expenditure Based Capital Minimum is calculated as per Section 3.7, while the Variable Capital Requirement is determined by a specific formula. The Variable Capital Requirement for a Money Remitter is calculated as the sum of 1.25% of the first $10 million of monthly payment volume, 0.5% of the next $90 million, 0.25% of the next $150 million, and 0.125% of any remaining monthly payment volume [#P:b1b3ae34-d42b-4c08-83fb-9ddac72f228c]. Additionally, if the Money Remitter is also acting as a Payment Account Provider, it must add the monthly payment volumes for both activities and perform the calculation as per Rule 3.6A.4 to determine the overall Variable Capital Requirement [#P:b68ce9bd-b816-410b-92f6-32569f63a223]. Ultimately, the Money Remitter must ensure that the calculated Capital Requirement is the highest of the applicable Base Capital Requirement, the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum, and the Total Variable Capital Requirement [#P:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304].

question: How does a Money Remitter figure out its Capital Requirement using both the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum and the Variable Capital Requirement?
gold_answer: A Money Remitter needs to find the highest value between the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum and the Variable Capital Requirement. The Variable Capital Requirement is calculated by adding up percentages of different parts of the monthly payment volume: 1.25% of the first $10 million, 0.5% of the next $90 million, 0.25% of the next $150 million, and 0.125% of any remaining volume [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304][#TGT:b1b3ae34-d42b-4c08-83fb-9ddac72f228c].

Next, the Money Remitter calculates its Variable Capital Requirement by applying specific percentages to different tiers of its monthly payment volume: 1.25% for the first $10 million, 0.5% for the next $90 million, 0.25% for the next $150 million, and 0.125% for any remaining volume [#P:b1b3ae34-d42b-4c08-83fb-9ddac72f228c]. The Money Remitter must then compare the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum and the Variable Capital Requirement, and select the higher of the two as its Capital Requirement [#P:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304]. This ensures that the Money Remitter maintains sufficient capital to cover its operational risks and obligations.

question: How must a Payment Account Provider calculate its Variable Capital Requirement, and what is the role of this calculation in determining the overall Capital Requirement for an Authorised Person providing money services?
gold_answer: A Payment Account Provider must calculate its Variable Capital Requirement by summing specific percentages of its monthly payment volume: 2.5% of the first $10 million, 1% of the next $90 million, 0.5% of the next $150 million, and 0.25% of any remaining volume [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4]. This Variable Capital Requirement is a component in determining the overall Capital Requirement for an Authorised Person with Financial Services Permission to provide money services. Specifically, the Authorised Person must calculate the Capital Requirement as the highest of the applicable Base Capital Requirement or the Variable Capital Requirement for a Payment Account Provider, among other potential calculations depending on the activities undertaken [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304].

This calculation plays a crucial role in determining the overall Capital Requirement for an Authorised Person providing money services. Specifically, when an Authorised Person undertakes multiple activities under Providing Money Services, it must determine its Capital Requirement as the highest of the Base Capital Requirement, the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum, and the Total Variable Capital Requirement, which includes the Variable Capital Requirement for each activity [#P:5f303f3f-61f2-4e64-9f2d-4854a93cf582]. If the Authorised Person acts as both a Money Remitter and a Payment Account Provider, it must add together the monthly payment volumes for these activities and perform the calculation as per Rule 3.6A.4 to determine the overall Variable Capital Requirement [#P:b68ce9bd-b816-410b-92f6-32569f63a223]. This ensures that the Authorised Person maintains sufficient capital to cover its operational risks across all its money service activities.

question: How must an Authorised Person, acting as both a Money Remitter and a Payment Account Provider, calculate its overall Variable Capital Requirement, considering the specific percentage tiers for monthly payment volumes?

question: How must an Authorised Person undertaking multiple activities under Providing Money Services calculate its Capital Requirement, considering the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum for different categories?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person engaged in multiple activities under Providing Money Services must determine its Capital Requirement by selecting the highest value among the Base Capital Requirement, the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum, and the Total Variable Capital Requirement [#SRC:5f303f3f-61f2-4e64-9f2d-4854a93cf582]. The Expenditure Based Capital Minimum varies depending on the category and whether the Authorised Person holds Client Assets, Relevant Money, or Insurance Money. Specifically, it is 18/52nds of the Annual Audited Expenditure if such assets are held, 13/52nds for Category 3B or 3C without these holdings, and 6/52nds for Category 4 without Insurance Money [#TGT:69f86dbc-ee25-4811-ae4b-6688fdbb498b].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person undertaking multiple activities under Providing Money Services must calculate its Capital Requirement by determining the highest of several specified measures. Additionally, the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum must be calculated according to the specific category of the Authorised Person. For those holding Client Assets, Relevant Money, or Insurance Money, this is 18/52nds of the Annual Audited Expenditure [#P:69f86dbc-ee25-4811-ae4b-6688fdbb498b]. For Category 3B or 3C entities not holding such assets, it is 13/52nds, and for Category 4 entities not holding Insurance Money, it is 6/52nds [#P:69f86dbc-ee25-4811-ae4b-6688fdbb498b]. Lastly, the Total Variable Capital Requirement must be calculated, which involves specific calculations for activities such as Money Remitting and Payment Account Providing, where applicable [#P:5f303f3f-61f2-4e64-9f2d-4854a93cf582]. The Authorised Person must then use the highest of these calculated values to determine its Capital Requirement, ensuring compliance with the regulatory framework.

question: If an Authorised Person does more than one money service activity, how do they figure out their Capital Requirement using the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person doing multiple money service activities must calculate their Capital Requirement by choosing the highest value from the Base Capital Requirement, the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum, and the Total Variable Capital Requirement [#SRC:5f303f3f-61f2-4e64-9f2d-4854a93cf582]. The Expenditure Based Capital Minimum depends on whether they hold Client Assets, Relevant Money, or Insurance Money. It is 18/52nds of the Annual Audited Expenditure if they hold these assets, 13/52nds for Category 3B or 3C without these holdings, and 6/52nds for Category 4 without Insurance Money [#TGT:69f86dbc-ee25-4811-ae4b-6688fdbb498b].

For those in Category 3B or 3C not holding such assets, it is 13/52nds, and for Category 4 without Insurance Money, it is 6/52nds of the AAE [#P:69f86dbc-ee25-4811-ae4b-6688fdbb498b]. Additionally, if the Authorised Person offers both currency exchange or Money Remittance and Payment Services, the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum is set at 18/52nds of the AAE [#P:eb147d12-3fa5-4b8a-ad72-1026e3fa9ded]. The Authorised Person must then compare this calculated Expenditure Based Capital Minimum with other capital requirements, such as the Base Capital Requirement and the Total Variable Capital Requirement, and adopt the highest value as their Capital Requirement [#P:5f303f3f-61f2-4e64-9f2d-4854a93cf582].

question: How must an Authorised Person calculate its Leverage Ratio, and what components are included in the Tier 1 Capital for this calculation?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to calculate its Leverage Ratio by dividing its Capital Measure by its Exposure Measure [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b]. The Capital Measure is defined as the Tier 1 Capital, which includes both Common Equity Tier 1 capital (CET1 Capital) and Additional Tier 1 capital (AT1 Capital) [#TGT:a2ce8a2e-9188-4d44-8582-42abbadc4f11]. The Exposure Measure is determined according to specific rules, namely Rules 3.21.5 and 3.21.6 [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b].

The "Capital Measure" is defined as the Tier 1 Capital of the Authorised Person, which is calculated by summing its Common Equity Tier 1 capital (CET1 Capital) and its Additional Tier 1 capital (AT1 Capital) [#P:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b][#P:a2ce8a2e-9188-4d44-8582-42abbadc4f11]. The "Exposure Measure" is the value of Exposures of the Authorised Person, calculated according to specific rules [#P:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b]. Additionally, an Authorised Person is required to maintain a minimum Leverage Ratio of 3% at all times, unless a different percentage is set by the Regulator [#P:e9e2bf18-6110-4e9f-8060-c59b85e5cd8e]. This ensures that the Authorised Person holds sufficient Tier 1 Capital relative to its total exposures, thereby maintaining financial stability and regulatory compliance. There are no specific timing, record-keeping, or notification requirements mentioned in the provided context, nor are there any exceptions or edge cases specified.

question: What is the Leverage Ratio calculation for an Authorised Person, and what makes up the Tier 1 Capital?

question: What risk weight must be applied to an unrated CR Exposure in the bank asset class if a short-term exposure with an issue-specific external credit assessment attracts a risk weight of 150%?

gold_answer: An Authorised Person must consider specific types of Investments as having particularly high risks under Rule 4.12.19, including investments in venture capital funds, hedge funds or alternative investment funds such as Private Equity Funds, speculative immovable property financing, and any Investments declared by the Regulator as high risk [#TGT:634d7695-6188-4cdb-bdd8-bc789adba744]. Additionally, the Authorised Person must assess the risk characteristics of the Exposure, specifically whether there is a high risk of loss due to the default of the obligor and if it is impossible to adequately assess this risk [#SRC:3d42a036-1c75-4f4c-882c-847760f2d90c].

question: Under what conditions may an Authorised Person apply a 0% risk weight to a CR Exposure, and how does this relate to the requirement of applying a 20% risk weight to certain items drawn on other banking institutions?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is permitted to apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure that is classified as a cash item, provided that it complies with Rule 4.12.3 [#SRC:881a93fe-965d-4247-98b7-13b0248c8b98]. However, when dealing with cheques, drafts, and other items drawn on other banking institutions, which are either payable immediately upon presentation or are in the process of collection, the Authorised Person must apply a 20% risk weight [#TGT:fa446f03-a066-46e1-beb1-d67d0862d0f8]. This distinction highlights the different risk weight applications based on the nature of the financial instrument and the institution involved.

Additionally, a 0% risk weight can be applied to certain transactions involving eligible financial collateral, such as qualifying SFTs with core market participants or OTC Derivative transactions collateralised by cash with no currency mismatch [#P:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438]. In contrast, an Authorised Person must apply a 20% risk weight to cheques, drafts, and other items drawn on other banking institutions that are either payable immediately upon presentation or in the process of collection [#P:fa446f03-a066-46e1-beb1-d67d0862d0f8]. The application of a 0% risk weight is contingent upon the nature of the CR Exposure and the specific conditions outlined in the rules, whereas the 20% risk weight is a mandatory requirement for certain items drawn on other banking institutions. These provisions ensure that risk weights are applied appropriately based on the type and conditions of the financial exposure.

question: What should an Authorised Person do if a CR Exposure in the central government and central bank asset class doesn't meet Rule 4.12.5?

question: Under what conditions may an Authorised Person apply a value of zero to HE, HC, and HS for an SFT involving Securities issued by central governments, and how does this relate to the risk weighting of CR Exposures in the central government and central bank asset class?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may apply a value of zero to HE, HC, and HS in the case of a Securities Financing Transaction (SFT) where both the Exposure and Collateral are Securities issued by central governments, provided that a value of zero has been prescribed by the banking regulator of that jurisdiction and the Exposures to the central government have a Credit Quality Grade of 1 [#SRC:ed63c9d6-51da-4984-9431-9a2ca8dc0d03]. [#P:bedaa8b8-4488-4156-9886-a8e1e2edd6b8] Exposures to certain MDBs, such as the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank, and the European Commission, are assigned a 0% risk weight, meaning they are considered risk-free for credit risk purposes. [#P:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16] This 0% risk weight applies specifically to these institutions, while other MDB exposures are risk-weighted according to their credit quality grade, ranging from 0% to 150% depending on the grade. [#P:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c] The use of guarantees from MDBs is contingent upon the MDB being recognized as an eligible guarantor, and the exposure must be risk-weighted appropriately based on the MDB's credit quality grade unless it falls under the specific institutions mentioned with a 0% risk weight. [#P:bedaa8b8-4488-4156-9886-a8e1e2edd6b8]

question: When can an Authorised Person use a 0% risk weight for a CR Exposure with a guarantee from a multilateral development bank, and who can provide these guarantees?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person can use a 0% risk weight for a CR Exposure if it involves certain multilateral development banks like the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank, or the European Commission [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16]. The guarantee must be from entities such as central governments, central banks, specific MDBs mentioned in Rule 4.12.8, international organisations in Rule 4.12.9, public sector enterprises, banks and securities firms in the bank asset class, or any entity with a credit rating of Credit Quality Grade 3 or better [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d].

The MDBs that can provide such guarantees include the World Bank Group (comprising the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency, and the International Finance Corporation), the Asian Development Bank, the African Development Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the Inter American Development Bank, the European Investment Bank, the European Investment Fund, the Nordic Investment Bank, the Caribbean Development Bank, the Islamic Development Bank, and the Council of Europe Development Bank [#P:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]. Additionally, when considering the guarantee, there must not be any maturity mismatch between the guarantee and the underlying exposure [#P:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]. This ensures that the exposure is effectively covered by the guarantee throughout its duration, allowing the Authorised Person to treat the exposure as if it were incurred to the MDB providing the guarantee, rather than to the original client [#P:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e].

question: Under what conditions may an Authorised Person recognise the Netting of an on balance sheet Exposure against an offsetting on balance sheet item, and what specific legal documentation is required to support this recognition?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may recognise the Netting of an on balance sheet Exposure against an offsetting on balance sheet item if the Netting agreement satisfies the conditions outlined in Rule 4.13.19 [#SRC:6446b9df-ac01-4d04-bb14-029e92f0b3f7]. Specifically, the agreement must meet several criteria: both the Exposure and the offsetting item must be between the Authorised Person and the same Counterparty, and the Netting must align with the Authorised Person's legal rights against the Counterparty [#TGT:f3f3a9ac-35d6-4ee0-9390-c8543c3da4cf]. Additionally, a legal right of set off must exist, and the agreement must not include a Walkaway Clause [#TGT:f3f3a9ac-35d6-4ee0-9390-c8543c3da4cf]. The Netting must be enforceable in cases of default or similar circumstances, and both the Exposure and offsetting item must be managed on a net basis [#TGT:f3f3a9ac-35d6-4ee0-9390-c8543c3da4cf]. Furthermore, the Authorised Person must have a written legal opinion from an external legal advisor confirming these conditions are met across all relevant jurisdictions, and this opinion must be regularly reviewed to remain current [#TGT:f3f3a9ac-35d6-4ee0-9390-c8543c3da4cf].

A legal right of set-off must exist, and the agreement should not contain a Walkaway Clause. The Netting must be effective and enforceable in cases of default, bankruptcy, or similar circumstances affecting either party [#P:f3f3a9ac-35d6-4ee0-9390-c8543c3da4cf]. Additionally, the Exposure and offsetting item must be managed on a net basis, and any potential for roll-off Exposure must be controlled if there is a Maturity Mismatch [#P:f3f3a9ac-35d6-4ee0-9390-c8543c3da4cf]. Furthermore, a written and reasoned legal opinion from an external legal advisor is required, confirming that these conditions are met for all relevant jurisdictions, and this opinion must be kept up to date [#P:f3f3a9ac-35d6-4ee0-9390-c8543c3da4cf]. This ensures that the Netting agreement is legally sound and enforceable.

question: When can an Authorised Person count a Netting agreement for on balance sheet items, and what legal checks are needed?

question: What are the obligations of an Authorised Person to recognise the effects of CRM when using eligible financial Collateral under the FCCA, and how do the requirements of Rule 4.13.8 interact with the types of Collateral specified in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must comply with the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 to recognise the effects of Credit Risk Mitigation (CRM) for the types of Collateral specified in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7 [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8]. When using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral includes instruments listed in Rule 4.13.5, equity Securities traded on a regulated exchange, and Units in a Collective Investment Fund investing primarily in such equity Securities [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]. The interaction between these rules ensures that the Authorised Person adheres to specific conditions for CRM recognition, such as ensuring that the Fund's Units are publicly quoted daily and that a significant portion of the Fund's property is invested in eligible instruments [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85].

Eligible financial Collateral under the FCCA includes instruments listed in Rule 4.13.5, equity Securities traded on a regulated exchange, and Units in a Collective Investment Fund that meet certain criteria [#P:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]. To recognise the effects of CRM, the Authorised Person must ensure compliance with the requirements set out in Rule 4.13.8, which apply to the types of Collateral specified in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7 [#P:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8]. This involves ensuring that the Collateral meets the eligibility criteria and is appropriately valued and managed to mitigate credit risk effectively. The Authorised Person must also maintain accurate records and documentation to demonstrate compliance with these requirements. There are no specific timing or notification requirements mentioned in the provided context, but adherence to the rules and maintaining compliance documentation is crucial. This structured approach ensures that the financial Collateral is effectively utilised to mitigate credit risk, aligning with regulatory expectations.

question: If an Authorised Person wants to use financial Collateral under the FCCA, what must they do to recognise CRM effects, and what types of Collateral are eligible?
gold_answer: To recognise the effects of Credit Risk Mitigation (CRM) when using financial Collateral under the FCCA, an Authorised Person must comply with the requirements in Rule 4.13.8 [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8]. Eligible financial Collateral includes instruments listed in Rule 4.13.5, equity Securities traded on a regulated exchange, and Units in a Collective Investment Fund that invests mainly in such equity Securities [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]. The Fund's Units must have a daily quoted price, and a large portion of the Fund's property must be invested in eligible instruments [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85].

Eligible types of Collateral are those set out in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, and the Authorised Person must ensure compliance with the requirements in Rule 4.13.8 to recognise the CRM effects [#P:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8]. For pre-settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from Securities Financing Transactions (SFTs) in the Trading Book, the FCCA is the only permissible approach to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral [#P:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]. question: How must an Authorised Person ensure compliance with the requirements for recognising CRM effects of Collateral under Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, particularly when dealing with Counterparty Risk Exposures from an SFT included in the Trading Book?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must comply with the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 to recognise the effects of CRM for the types of Collateral specified in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7 [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8]. When these exposures arise from a Securities Financing Transaction (SFT) included in the Trading Book, the eligible financial Collateral encompasses all instruments that may be included in the Trading Book [#TGT:cacd95d6-558b-4d84-93f1-e1d5664a1d01]. Thus, the Authorised Person must ensure that both the compliance with Rule 4.13.8 and the inclusion of eligible financial instruments in the Trading Book are addressed.

question: When an Authorised Person opts for the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA), what are the specific criteria for eligible financial Collateral, and how does this relate to the instruments listed in Rule 4.13.5?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person choosing the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA) must ensure that eligible financial Collateral includes any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5, any equity Security traded on a regulated exchange, and any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund investing in such equity Securities [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]. The FCCA requires adherence to the treatment under Rule 4.13.6, which is distinct from the Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) that follows Rule 4.13.5 [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19]. For Units in a Collective Investment Fund to qualify, a daily public price quote must be available, and at least 90% of the Fund's deposited property must be invested in instruments listed in the relevant rules [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85].
rag_answer: When an Authorised Person opts for the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA), the specific criteria for eligible financial Collateral include any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5, any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange, and any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in such equity Securities. For the latter, it is required that a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily and that at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in Rule 4.13.6 and Rule 4.13.5 [#P:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]. It is important to note that eligible financial Collateral excludes any T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person, which is held by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities as Collateral [#P:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685]. This approach must be applied consistently across the Non Trading Book, and for pre-settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from any SFT in the Trading Book, only the FCCA can be used [#P:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412].

question: What are the specific requirements an Authorised Person must comply with to recognise the effects of CRM for Collateral, and how do these requirements relate to the rules set out in Rule 4.13.8?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must comply with several specific requirements before recognising the effects of CRM for Collateral. These requirements include ensuring that the legal mechanism for pledging, assigning, or transferring Collateral grants the Authorised Person the right to liquidate or take legal possession of the Collateral in a timely manner in the event of default, insolvency, or bankruptcy of the Counterparty, or other defined credit events [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1]. Additionally, the Authorised Person must take all necessary steps under applicable law to maintain an enforceable security interest, such as registering it with a registrar or exercising a right to net or set off [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1]. These requirements are part of the broader obligations outlined in Rule 4.13.8, which must be adhered to for the recognition of CRM effects [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8].
rag_answer: To recognise the effects of Credit Risk Mitigation (CRM) for Collateral, an Authorised Person must comply with specific requirements outlined in Rule 4.13.8. These requirements ensure that the legal and operational framework for handling Collateral is robust and enforceable. Firstly, the legal mechanism for pledging, assigning, or transferring Collateral must allow the Authorised Person to liquidate or take possession of the Collateral promptly in case of default or insolvency of the Counterparty or custodian [#P:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1]. The Authorised Person must also take necessary legal steps to maintain an enforceable security interest, such as registering it with a registrar [#P:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1]. Additionally, there should be no material positive correlation between the credit quality of the Counterparty and the value of the Collateral, and securities issued by the Counterparty or any closely related entity are not eligible as Collateral [#P:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1]. Procedures must be in place for the timely liquidation of Collateral, ensuring legal conditions for declaring default and liquidation are met [#P:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1]. Lastly, if a custodian holds the Collateral, the Authorised Person must ensure it is segregated from the custodian's assets [#P:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1]. These requirements are crucial for the effective recognition of CRM effects.

question: How must an Authorised Person handle deductions from CET1 Capital when dealing with Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips and increases in issued capital or reserves from securitisation?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to deduct 100% of Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips from CET1 Capital, net of any deductions mandated by Rule 4.14.13 [#SRC:c0b36aad-933a-4667-a073-ebb69b3f1aab]. Additionally, any increase in issued capital or reserves resulting from a securitisation, such as gains on sale linked to expected future margin income, must also be deducted from CET1 Capital [#TGT:6300f7af-226b-41ca-ac50-e4802726964c]. These deductions ensure that the CET1 Capital accurately reflects the financial position without inflating capital through securitisation gains or interest-only strips.

Additionally, any increase in issued capital or reserves resulting from a securitisation, such as those associated with expected future margin income leading to a gain on sale, must also be deducted from CET1 Capital [#P:6300f7af-226b-41ca-ac50-e4802726964c]. These deductions ensure that the CET1 Capital accurately reflects the financial position of the Authorised Person without artificial inflation from securitisation activities. It is crucial for the Authorised Person to adhere to these requirements to maintain compliance with regulatory standards and ensure the integrity of their capital calculations.

question: What are the obligations of an Originator if it fails to comply with Rule 4.14.15 regarding a securitisation, and how does this relate to the prohibition on providing Implicit Support?
gold_answer: If an Originator fails to comply with Rule 4.14.15 in respect of a securitisation, it must include all the underlying Exposures of the securitisation in its calculation of Credit RWAs as if those Exposures had not been securitised and were on the balance sheet of the Authorised Person [#SRC:5443b1af-d668-49ad-8014-990d90fcba1c]. Additionally, the Originator must not recognise any gain on sale of assets to the securitisation and must disclose to investors that the Authorised Person has provided non-contractual support and the regulatory capital impact of doing so [#SRC:5443b1af-d668-49ad-8014-990d90fcba1c]. This is related to the prohibition on providing Implicit Support, as an Originator or a Sponsor must not provide such support to a securitisation transaction with the intent of reducing potential or actual losses to investors outside of its contractual obligations [#TGT:a7d00358-0608-4ba6-b012-36de1be9cc2f].

If this rule is violated, the Originator must take the following actions: 

- Include all the underlying Exposures of the securitisation in its calculation of Credit RWAs as if those Exposures had not been securitised and were on the balance sheet of the Authorised Person [#P:5443b1af-d668-49ad-8014-990d90fcba1c].
- Not recognise any gain on the sale of assets to the securitisation [#P:5443b1af-d668-49ad-8014-990d90fcba1c].
- Disclose to investors that the Authorised Person has provided non-contractual support and the regulatory capital impact of doing so [#P:5443b1af-d668-49ad-8014-990d90fcba1c].

These obligations ensure transparency and maintain the integrity of the securitisation process by addressing the regulatory capital implications of providing Implicit Support.

question: Under what conditions must an Authorised Person continue to hold regulatory capital against securitisation Exposures, and how does this relate to the exclusion of Synthetic Securitisation from RWA calculations?

question: When an Authorised Person applies CRM to an Exposure within a securitisation, how should the Exposure be treated in the Trading Book, and what are the implications for the Capital Requirement?

This ensures that the treatment of Exposures in the Trading Book aligns with the operational requirements for external credit assessments, maintaining consistency across different books.

question: How should an Authorised Person conduct periodic stress testing for securitisation activities to ensure comprehensive risk management, considering both firm-wide impacts and future transaction capabilities?

These stress tests should evaluate the firm-wide impact of these activities under stressed market conditions, including the implications for other sources of risk [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97]. Additionally, the tests must assess the future ability to transact securitisation as a means of credit risk mitigation (CRM) or for liquidity purposes [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa]. This comprehensive approach ensures that both current and potential future risks are adequately managed.

These tests should also assess the future ability to use securitisation for credit risk mitigation (CRM) or liquidity purposes [#P:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa]. The frequency and extent of these stress tests should be determined based on the materiality of the Authorised Person's securitisation volumes and off-balance sheet exposures [#P:053ecf47-4501-4027-a994-9ada059b5e73]. Additionally, the stress tests should include an evaluation of market value changes of underlying collateral, liquidity risks, and the realisation of such collateral in stress scenarios, with an assessment of the impact on exposure value and the capital position of the Authorised Person [#P:d26a7df5-05be-4235-8dc2-0a8a4e548f9f]. These stress tests should be conducted at least annually to ensure ongoing risk management effectiveness [#P:d26a7df5-05be-4235-8dc2-0a8a4e548f9f].

question: What should an Authorised Person do if they are the Originator or Sponsor of a securitisation with revolving exposures and an Early Amortisation clause?

question: In the context of Credit Risk mitigation, how should an Authorised Person adjust the Exposure value when the Collateral value under a stress scenario is lower than the value applied under Rule 4.15.12, and what options are available for reducing Exposures?

These measures ensure that the Exposure values reflect the true risk profile under stressed conditions.

question: If the Collateral value is lower in a stress test than what Rule 4.15.12 says, what should an Authorised Person do, and what are some ways to lower Exposures?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person should use the lower Collateral value from the stress test when figuring out the Exposure value [#SRC:50586097-115d-49d1-9dd6-462b2d08e3f3]. They can also lower Exposures by using specific provisions for credit loss risks, netting claims and liabilities with a Counterparty, holding certain types of Collateral, using eligible guarantees, applying Credit Derivatives, and doing securitisation transactions, as long as they meet the rules in Sections 4.13 and 4.14 [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3].
rag_answer:
If the value of Collateral is lower in a stress test than the value applied under Rule 4.15.12, an Authorised Person must use the lower value when determining the Exposure value for regulatory purposes. [#P:50586097-115d-49d1-9dd6-462b2d08e3f3] To lower Exposures, an Authorised Person can consider the following methods: 

- If Exposures to a Client are guaranteed by a third party or secured by Collateral issued by a third party, and the Collateral or guarantee meets the requirements of Section 4.13 (CRM) and would be assigned a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, the portion of the Exposure secured by Collateral or guaranteed can be treated as an Exposure to the third party. This allows the Authorised Person to consider the Exposure as incurred to the third party rather than the Client for the purposes of the limits set out at Rule 4.15.5. [#P:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]
- If an Exposure is partially guaranteed by an Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution and would be assigned a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, only that part of the Exposure subject to the guarantee is exempt from the Large Exposure limit in Rule 4.15.5. [#P:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3]

These methods help manage and potentially reduce the regulatory impact of Exposures.

question: How must an Authorised Person document its policy for using exclusions in Rule 4.15.12 when reducing the value of its Exposures under Section 4.13 conditions?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to document its policy for utilizing any exclusions in Rule 4.15.12 as part of its recognition of Credit Risk mitigations [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270]. This documentation must align with the discretion allowed to reduce the value of its Exposures by specific provisions, netting, collateral, eligible guarantees, credit derivatives, and securitisation, provided the conditions in Section 4.13 are met [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person must document its policy for using exclusions in Rule 4.15.12 by clearly outlining the procedures and conditions under which it will reduce the value of its Exposures, ensuring compliance with Section 4.13 conditions. This documentation should include the specific methods of reduction, such as the use of specific provisions, netting, collateral, guarantees, credit derivatives, and securitisation, as outlined in Rule 4.15.12 [#P:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3]. The policy must also detail the criteria for recognizing these credit risk mitigations, ensuring that all conditions and requirements specified in Section 4.13 are met, such as the eligibility of collateral and guarantees, and the absence of maturity mismatches in guarantees [#P:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]. Additionally, the policy should include procedures for monitoring and controlling Exposures on a daily basis, and for notifying the Regulator immediately of any breaches of the limits set out in the relevant sections [#P:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]. This comprehensive documentation ensures that the Authorised Person's approach to credit risk mitigation is transparent, consistent, and compliant with regulatory requirements.

question: When can an Authorised Person reduce its Exposures, and what must it do about exclusions in Rule 4.15.12?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person can reduce its Exposures by using specific provisions, netting, collateral, guarantees, credit derivatives, and securitisation, as long as the conditions in Section 4.13 are satisfied [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3]. It must also document its policy for using any exclusions in Rule 4.15.12 related to Credit Risk mitigations [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person can reduce its Exposures by utilizing credit risk mitigations, such as guarantees or Collateral, provided these meet the requirements set out in Section 4.13 (CRM) and would be assigned a lower risk weight under Section 4.12. When Exposures are guaranteed by a third party or secured by Collateral issued by a third party, the Authorised Person may treat the secured or guaranteed portion of the Exposure as being incurred to the third party rather than to the Client, for the purposes of considering the limits set out at Rule 4.15.5. This is contingent on there being no Maturity Mismatch between the guarantee and the underlying Exposure [#P:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]. Additionally, an Authorised Person must document its policy for the use of any exclusions in Rule 4.15.12, ensuring that the policy is clearly articulated and maintained [#P:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270]. This documentation is crucial for regulatory compliance and for providing a clear framework for the application of exclusions in managing credit risk.

question: Under what conditions can an Authorised Person exclude an Exposure from the Large Exposure limits due to a parental guarantee, and how does this relate to exemptions for partially guaranteed Exposures?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may exclude an Exposure from the Large Exposure limits if the Parent is committed to increasing the Authorised Person's Tier 1 capital promptly and on demand, or if the Parent guarantees the Exposure under specific conditions [#TGT:032faf55-93b1-4f6a-ab8f-56eea4f82cff]. These conditions include the guarantee being provided by the Parent or a regulated Group member, compliance with CRM requirements, and the Parent having a high credit quality grade, among others [#TGT:032faf55-93b1-4f6a-ab8f-56eea4f82cff]. Additionally, if an Exposure is partially guaranteed by the Parent Financial Institution, only the guaranteed portion is exempt from the Large Exposure limit, as per Rule 4.15.5 [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3]. The Authorised Person may also consider exemptions under Rule 4.15.18 when evaluating these guarantees [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person can exclude an Exposure from the Large Exposure limits due to a parental guarantee under specific conditions. Firstly, the Parent must be committed to increasing the Authorised Person's Tier 1 capital promptly and on demand, either to cover any potential losses from the Exposure or to ensure compliance with Capital Requirements [#P:032faf55-93b1-4f6a-ab8f-56eea4f82cff]. Additionally, the Parent or a regulated Group member must guarantee the Exposure, provided the guarantee meets the Credit Risk Mitigation (CRM) requirements and the entity providing the guarantee is a bank regulated to acceptable standards [#P:032faf55-93b1-4f6a-ab8f-56eea4f82cff]. The total guarantees must be less than 10% of the Tier 1 of the entity providing the guarantee, and the Parent must have a high credit rating [#P:032faf55-93b1-4f6a-ab8f-56eea4f82cff]. Furthermore, the Authorised Person must confirm annually that the guarantees remain enforceable and notify the Regulator when guarantees reach certain thresholds relative to Tier 1 [#P:032faf55-93b1-4f6a-ab8f-56eea4f82cff]. For partially guaranteed Exposures, only the portion covered by the guarantee is exempt from the Large Exposure limit, and the Authorised Person may also consider exemptions related to parental guarantees [#P:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3].

question: How can an Authorised Person exclude an Exposure from Large Exposure limits using a parental guarantee, and what happens if only part of the Exposure is guaranteed?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person can exclude an Exposure from Large Exposure limits if the Parent agrees to increase the Authorised Person's Tier 1 capital or guarantees the Exposure under certain rules [#TGT:032faf55-93b1-4f6a-ab8f-56eea4f82cff]. These rules require the Parent to be a regulated bank with a good credit rating and to follow specific guarantee criteria [#TGT:032faf55-93b1-4f6a-ab8f-56eea4f82cff]. If only part of the Exposure is guaranteed by the Parent Financial Institution, only that part is exempt from the Large Exposure limit [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3]. The Authorised Person can also look at other exemptions related to parental guarantees [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3].
